**Falcon** (**Samuel Thomas "Sam" Wilson**) is a
[fictional](/wiki/Fictional_character "Fictional character")
[superhero](/wiki/Superhero "Superhero") appearing in [American comic
books](/wiki/American_comic_book "American comic book") published by [Marvel
Comics](/wiki/Marvel_Comics "Marvel Comics"). The character was created by
writer-editor [Stan Lee](/wiki/Stan_Lee "Stan Lee") and artist [Gene
Colan](/wiki/Gene_Colan "Gene Colan"), and introduced in _[Captain
America](/wiki/Captain_America_\(comic_book\) "Captain America \(comic
book\)")_ #117 (Sept. 1969). As the superhero Falcon, Wilson uses mechanical
wings to fly, granting him limited telepathic and empathic control over birds.
Following Steve Rogers' retirement, Wilson becomes the newest **Captain
America** and leader of the [Avengers](/wiki/Avengers_\(comics\) "Avengers
\(comics\)").

Wilson's deceased nephew was the [Incredible Hulk](/wiki/Hulk_\(comics\) "Hulk
\(comics\)")'s sometime-sidekick [Jim Wilson](/wiki/Jim_Wilson_\(comics\) "Jim
Wilson \(comics\)"), one of the first openly [HIV-positive](/wiki/HIV-positive
"HIV-positive") comic-book characters. Jim Wilson's father Gideon Wilson would
go on to join the [Gamma Corps](/wiki/Gamma_Corps "Gamma Corps"). Sam also has
parents named Paul and Darlene Wilson, a sister named Sarah Casper, a nephew
named Jody Toby Casper,[1] and an unnamed niece.[2]

[Anthony Mackie](/wiki/Anthony_Mackie "Anthony Mackie") portrays Sam Wilson /
Falcon in the 2014 [Marvel Studios](/wiki/Marvel_Studios "Marvel Studios")
film, _[Captain America: The Winter
Soldier](/wiki/Captain_America:_The_Winter_Soldier "Captain America: The
Winter Soldier")_ and reprises his role in _[Avengers: Age of
Ultron](/wiki/Avengers:_Age_of_Ultron "Avengers: Age of Ultron")_ (2015),
_[Ant-Man](/wiki/Ant-Man_\(film\) "Ant-Man \(film\)")_ (2015), _[Captain
America: Civil War](/wiki/Captain_America:_Civil_War "Captain America: Civil
War")_ (2016), _[Avengers: Infinity War](/wiki/Avengers:_Infinity_War
"Avengers: Infinity War")_ (2018) and is set to reprise his role in the fourth
_[Avengers film](/wiki/Untitled_Avengers_film "Untitled Avengers film")_
(2019).

## Publication
history[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Falcon_\(comics\)&action=edit&section=1
"Edit section: Publication history")]

**Samuel Thomas Wilson** , known as the Falcon, was the first African-American
[superhero](/wiki/Superhero "Superhero") in mainstream [comic
books](/wiki/Comic_books "Comic books"),[3] and also the first black superhero
not to have the word "black" as part of his superhero name.[a] The character
[first appeared](/wiki/First_appeared "First appeared") in _[Captain
America](/wiki/Captain_America_\(comic_book\) "Captain America \(comic
book\)")_ #117 (Sept. 1969).[4]

Created by writer-editor [Stan Lee](/wiki/Stan_Lee "Stan Lee") and artist
[Gene Colan](/wiki/Gene_Colan "Gene Colan"),[4] he came about, Colan recalled
in 2008,

> ...in the late 1960s [when news of the] [Vietnam War](/wiki/Vietnam_War
> "Vietnam War") and [civil rights](/wiki/Civil_rights "Civil rights")
> protests were regular occurrences, and Stan, always wanting to be at the
> forefront of things, started bringing these headlines into the comics. ...
> One of the biggest steps we took in this direction came in _Captain
> America_. I enjoyed drawing people of every kind. I drew as many different
> types of people as I could into the scenes I illustrated, and I loved
> drawing black people. I always found their features interesting and so much
> of their strength, spirit and wisdom written on their faces. I approached
> Stan, as I remember, with the idea of introducing an African-American hero
> and he took to it right away. ... I looked at several African-American
> magazines, and used them as the basis of inspiration for bringing The Falcon
> to life.[5]

He was introduced as an unnamed former resident of [New York
City](/wiki/New_York_City "New York City")'s [Harlem](/wiki/Harlem "Harlem")
neighborhood, who had adopted a wild falcon he trained and named Redwing. (His
own name, **Sam Wilson** , was not given until page five of the following
issue.) When a group of men on an island "in the tropics" wanted a hunting
falcon, Wilson answered the ad, only to discover that the self-dubbed "Exiles"
were former [Nazis](/wiki/Nazi "Nazi") in league with the
[supervillain](/wiki/Supervillain "Supervillain") the [Red
Skull](/wiki/Red_Skull "Red Skull"). He escaped, but remained on the island to
organize the natives to confront the Exiles, who had turned them into
[serfs](/wiki/Serf "Serf"). At the urging of Steve Rogers, whom he later
learned was Captain America, Wilson took on the costumed identity of the
**Falcon** and underwent training with Rogers in order to better inspire the
villagers and lead the fight.[6]

Through most of the 1970s, the Falcon and Captain America were a team in New
York City, and the series was cover-billed _Captain America and the Falcon_
from issues #134–192 and 194–222 (February 1971 – June 1978),[7] though still
copyrighted as _Captain America_. In issue #186 (June 1975), writer [Steve
Englehart](/wiki/Steve_Englehart "Steve Englehart")
[retconned](/wiki/Retconned "Retconned") aspects of the Falcon's past.
Originally depicted as a former [social worker](/wiki/Social_worker "Social
worker"), motivated by a desire to better the lives of inner-city youth, the
Falcon was revealed as a mob-connected thug whose memories were altered by the
reality-warping [Cosmic Cube](/wiki/Cosmic_Cube "Cosmic Cube").

The Falcon briefly joined the superhero team the
[Defenders](/wiki/Defenders_\(comics\) "Defenders \(comics\)"), appearing in
issues #62–64 (August–October 1978), and was a member of the
[Avengers](/wiki/Avengers_\(comics\) "Avengers \(comics\)") from issues
#183–194 (May 1979 – April 1980). During this time he also starred in a solo
adventure in issue #49 of the try-out series _[Marvel
Premiere](/wiki/Marvel_Premiere "Marvel Premiere")_ ; however, the story was
not a try-out for a Falcon series, but an intended fill-in issue of _Captain
America_ which was shuffled into _Marvel Premiere_ when the editors objected
to having an issue of _Captain America_ with someone other than the title
character as the star.[8] He starred in his own four-issue miniseries in 1983,
written by [Jim Owsley](/wiki/Jim_Owsley "Jim Owsley"). Its first issue was
illustrated by [Paul Smith](/wiki/Paul_Smith_\(comics\) "Paul Smith
\(comics\)") with the final three issues by [Mark Bright](/wiki/M._D._Bright
"M. D. Bright"). The series revealed that the Falcon was a
[mutant](/wiki/Mutant_\(comics\) "Mutant \(comics\)"), although this
development was later retconned in the _Avengers 2001 Annual_.[9]

After regularly appearing in _Captain America_ vol. 2 (November 1996 –
November 1997), the Falcon rejoined the Avengers in _The Avengers_ vol. 3, #1
(February 1998). This time, he remained with the team, becoming one of its
most prominent members by issue #57 (Oct. 2002). Concurrently, he was also a
supporting character in _Captain America_ vols. 3–4 (January 1998 – February
2002 and June 2002 – December 2004). The Falcon next appeared in the short-
lived _[Captain America and the Falcon](/wiki/Captain_America_and_the_Falcon
"Captain America and the Falcon")_ series, in 2004 and 2005. After the events
of the storyline "[Avengers Disassembled](/wiki/Avengers_Disassembled
"Avengers Disassembled")", when the [Scarlet Witch](/wiki/Scarlet_Witch
"Scarlet Witch") temporarily restored his criminal personality, the Falcon
became a supporting character in _Captain America_ vol. 5 (January 2005 – July
2009). The Falcon continued to play a significant role in the series after it
returned to its original numbering, beginning with _Captain America_ #600
(Aug. 2009).

Falcon was a member of the Avengers in the 2012 [Marvel
NOW!](/wiki/Marvel_NOW! "Marvel NOW!") relaunch.[10]

On July 16, 2014 Marvel Comics announced that Sam Wilson would relinquish the
mantle of Falcon and would become the new [Captain
America](/wiki/Captain_America "Captain America"), succeeding Steve Rogers in
the role.[11] An ongoing series starring Sam Wilson as Captain America
launched in October 2015, as part of Marvel's post-_[Secret
Wars](/wiki/Secret_Wars_\(2015_comic_book\) "Secret Wars \(2015 comic
book\)")_ relaunch, written by Nick Spencer and Daniel Acuña.[12]

Wilson temporarily returns to the role of Captain America in the 2017
miniseries _[Marvel's Generations](/wiki/Generations_\(comics\) "Generations
\(comics\)")_.[13]

Wilson resumed the identity of Falcon in a series written by Rodney Barnes
that debuted in late 2017, the character's first solo series since
1983.[14][15]

## Fictional character
biography[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Falcon_\(comics\)&action=edit&section=2
"Edit section: Fictional character biography")]

### Early
life[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Falcon_\(comics\)&action=edit&section=3 "Edit
section: Early life")]

Samuel Thomas Wilson was born in [Harlem](/wiki/Harlem "Harlem"), [New York
City](/wiki/New_York_City "New York City"), to Paul Wilson, a prominent
minister, and Darlene Wilson. Wilson has a happy childhood and finds he has a
natural affinity for birds. He takes up training pigeons, and has the largest
pigeon coop in Harlem.[16] In his teens, however, encounters with racism leave
him jaded.[17] When he is 16, Wilson refuses to join the church, believing his
deeply religious parents to be ignorant for their faith. To his surprise,
rather than put up a fight, his parents provide him with books on different
religions and comparative theology. The next night, however, Sam's father is
killed trying to break up a neighborhood fight (originally Paul was said to
have been killed when Sam was 9 years old).[18] Two years later, his mother is
shot and killed by a mugger one block from their apartment. Consumed by grief
and "angry at the world" Sam turns his back on his past as a respected
community volunteer. He moves to [Los Angeles](/wiki/Los_Angeles "Los
Angeles") and creates a new persona: "Snap" Wilson, a professional criminal
and gang member.[19][20]

While Snap is on his way to "a big score in [Rio de
Janeiro](/wiki/Rio_de_Janeiro "Rio de Janeiro")", his plane crashes on Exile
Island (years later, he would say "I actually loved this place quite a bit.
It's where I met my two best friends," referring to Captain America and
Redwing).[21] The once-peaceful island had been taken over by the
[Exiles](/wiki/Exiles_\(Red_Skull_allies\) "Exiles \(Red Skull allies\)"), a
group of would-be world conquerors who had collaborated with the
[Nazi](/wiki/Nazi "Nazi") [supervillain](/wiki/Supervillain "Supervillain")
the [Red Skull](/wiki/Red_Skull "Red Skull") during [World War
II](/wiki/World_War_II "World War II"). They had been betrayed by the Red
Skull and were forced to remain in hiding on the island, enslaving the
natives. Wilson finds and befriends [Redwing](/wiki/Redwing_\(Marvel_Comics\)
"Redwing \(Marvel Comics\)"), a falcon with which he feels a remarkably strong
bond.[22]

### Becoming the
Falcon[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Falcon_\(comics\)&action=edit&section=4 "Edit
section: Becoming the Falcon")]

As part of a plot against Captain America, the Red Skull uses the [Cosmic
Cube](/wiki/Cosmic_Cube "Cosmic Cube"), a creation that allows its user to
alter reality, to mentally fuse Wilson with Redwing, creating a "super-normal
mental link" that would, with time and concentration, give Wilson broad powers
over all birds.[23][24] Next, the Skull uses the Cube to rewrite the past and
erase the years Wilson had spent angrily living as Snap Wilson. In this new
history, Wilson was an upright and cheerful [social
worker](/wiki/Social_worker "Social worker") who is eventually lured to the
Exiles' island and organizes the natives to fight for their freedom. Steve
Rogers (Captain America) befriends him there and convinces Wilson to adopt a
persona to inspire the natives in their rebellion. The two create the costumed
persona the Falcon and train together extensively before attacking and
defeating the Exiles and the Red Skull.[16] The Falcon becomes Captain
America's regular partner in crime-fighting,[25] and briefly even takes on the
Captain America costume and identity when Rogers is believed to have been
killed.[26]

Later, again as the Falcon, Wilson receives help from the [Black
Panther](/wiki/Black_Panther_\(comics\) "Black Panther \(comics\)"), who
creates a harness for Wilson, allowing him to fly.[27] When Rogers briefly
abandons his Captain America identity, others attempt to take up the mantle,
including a young man named Roscoe whom the Falcon mentors. When the Red Skull
eventually kills Roscoe, Rogers again becomes Captain America.[28]

Soon afterward, the Red Skull reveals the Falcon's true past as Snap Wilson,
and unsuccessfully attempts to use the Cosmic Cube to make the Falcon kill
Captain America.[29] Now aware of his past but deciding to continue as a hero,
the Falcon is eventually named head of the Super Agents at the
[espionage](/wiki/Espionage "Espionage") agency
[S.H.I.E.L.D.](/wiki/S.H.I.E.L.D. "S.H.I.E.L.D.").[30]

US government superhero liaison [Henry Peter Gyrich](/wiki/Henry_Peter_Gyrich
"Henry Peter Gyrich") then recruits Wilson, one of the few active black
superheroes, to fill a mandated racial quota for the venerable team the
[Avengers](/wiki/Avengers_\(comics\) "Avengers \(comics\)").[31] Resentful of
being a "token", the Falcon quits at the first opportunity. He debuts a new
costume when he fights the supervillain
[Taskmaster](/wiki/Taskmaster_\(comics\) "Taskmaster \(comics\)").[32]

### 2000s[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Falcon_\(comics\)&action=edit&section=5
"Edit section: 2000s")]

Falcon becomes a member of the new team of Avengers assembled to fight the
international menace
[Scorpio](/w/index.php?title=S.C.O.R.P.I.O_\(comics\)&action=edit&redlink=1
"S.C.O.R.P.I.O \(comics\) \(page does not exist\)") as a United Nations
peacekeeping agency. By this point, Falcon had discovered that he could extend
his telepathic bond with Redwing, allowing him to control other birds and
"see" through their eyes. He uses this ability to spy on Henry Gyrich (now the
Avengers' liaison with the United Nations) and discovers that the United
States' Secretary of Defense, Dell Rusk, has been pressuring Gyrich to spy on
the Avengers and turn over their secrets. Although initially hostile to one
another, Falcon convinces Gyrich to help the Avengers spy on Rusk, feeding him
false information while gathering evidence to expose him. They discover that
Rusk is actually the Red Skull, who has launched a biological weapon attack on
America, intending to use the ensuing panic to gain control over America's
government and start a war with other countries. Falcon is instrumental in
defeating the Red Skull.[33]

It is around this period of time that, a new "Captain America" secretly
created by the [Office of Naval
Intelligence](/wiki/Office_of_Naval_Intelligence "Office of Naval
Intelligence") (O.N.I.) goes rogue and begins eliminating anything and anyone
he sees as a source of terrorism. To draw out this agent (dubbed "The [Anti-
Cap](/wiki/Anti-Cap "Anti-Cap")"), O.N.I. leaks information about their
involvement in a [biological weapons](/wiki/Biological_weapons "Biological
weapons") project with the notorious Rivas Family, powerful Cuban drug lords.
Reporter and social activist Leila Taylor investigates this rumor and attempts
to smuggle a sample of the virus into America, but she is arrested by U.S.
forces in Cuba. Falcon, who is a friend of Taylor, breaks her out of prison
and investigates her claims, destroying the Rivas Family's biological weapons
lab and obtaining a sample of the mysterious virus they were developing for
O.N.I. Falcon is able to fly Leila back to America (although his flying
harness is destroyed in a hurricane) while Captain America follows Falcon's
directions and retrieves the virus sample. The Anti-Cap kills the head of the
Rivas family, and pursues Leila, Falcon, and Cap, intent on obtaining the
virus sample. After reuniting, Falcon and Captain America are able to barely
defeat the Anti-Cap. Realizing that O.N.I.'s goal was to draw out their rogue
agent to execute him, Captain America arranges to have the Anti-Cap secretly
imprisoned in the Wakandan embassy until O.N.I. agrees not to kill him.[34]

Since Captain America and Falcon now possess both O.N.I.'s rogue agent and the
last remaining sample of O.N.I.'s virus, O.N.I. begins to put increasing
amounts of pressure on the heroes. Falcon is especially targeted – he had
broken Leila out of Federal Custody, and his criminal history makes it easier
for O.N.I. to create further false charges against him. Falcon soon finds
himself on the run from O.N.I.[_[volume & issue
needed](/wiki/Wikipedia:Citing_sources "Wikipedia:Citing sources")_]

Meanwhile, the superheroine the [Scarlet Witch](/wiki/Scarlet_Witch "Scarlet
Witch"), having gone insane, begins using her powers to re-create many of the
Avengers' greatest trials and tragedies. She destabilizes the Falcon's mind,
causing him to act increasingly like his "Snap" persona. He begins carrying a
gun, keeps secrets from his friends, assaults Leila's boyfriend Norman when he
protests they go into hiding, and uses a high power rifle to shoot at his
friend [Robbie Robertson](/wiki/Robbie_Robertson_\(comics\) "Robbie Robertson
\(comics\)") (to fool Robbie into thinking O.N.I. was threatening to kill
him). Although they succeed in exposing the illegal activities of O.N.I. and
clear Wilson's name, Sam's methods cause his relationship with Captain America
to become strained. Cap confronts Falcon about his recent actions, and Falcon,
angered at what he sees as an ultimatum, terminates their partnership. As they
are walking away, Norman (who blames Falcon for the end of his relationship
with Leila) appears and shoots at Falcon. Captain America is seriously injured
by the stray bullets, and even appears to die. The shock of watching his best
friend seemingly die because of his actions has a powerful affect on Sam, who
briefly gives up being Falcon and reexamines his life.[35]

Sam Wilson reappears as Falcon in the 2005 "[House of M](/wiki/House_of_M
"House of M")" storyline and in the 2006–07 "[Civil
War](/wiki/Civil_War_\(comics\) "Civil War \(comics\)")" storyline.[36] In the
latter, he supports Captain America against the [Superhuman Registration
Act](/wiki/Superhuman_Registration_Act "Superhuman Registration Act"). When
the Captain becomes incapacitated, Falcon temporarily assumes leadership of
the "Secret Avengers" rebel group.[37] Following Captain America's
assassination by the machinations of the Red Skull, the Falcon registers with
the government and is made responsible for Harlem, although he continues to
maintain contact with the underground [New
Avengers](/wiki/The_New_Avengers_\(comics\) "The New Avengers
\(comics\)").[38] He is also called upon to investigate the Captain's
assassination by locating [Winter Soldier](/wiki/Bucky_Barnes "Bucky Barnes")
and tracking down the Red Skull.[39]

### Becoming Captain
America[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Falcon_\(comics\)&action=edit&section=6
"Edit section: Becoming Captain America")]

[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/en/thumb/0/03/All-
New_Captain_America_Vol_1_1.jpg/170px-All-
New_Captain_America_Vol_1_1.jpg)](/wiki/File:All-
New_Captain_America_Vol_1_1.jpg)

[](/wiki/File:All-New_Captain_America_Vol_1_1.jpg "Enlarge")

Wilson as Captain America on the cover of _All-New Captain America_ #1
(November 2014). Art by [Stuart Immonen](/wiki/Stuart_Immonen "Stuart
Immonen").

Wilson appears in the 2010 "[Shadowland](/wiki/Shadowland_\(comics\)
"Shadowland \(comics\)")" storyline as Falcon, after which he becomes an
operative in the new incarnation of the [Heroes for
Hire](/wiki/Heroes_for_Hire "Heroes for Hire") team, in the book of the same
name.[40] He later appears in the 2012 "[Avengers vs.
X-Men](/wiki/Avengers_vs._X-Men "Avengers vs. X-Men")" storyline, helping
[She-Hulk](/wiki/She-Hulk "She-Hulk") and several other Avengers contain the
students at the [Jean Grey School for Higher
Learning](/wiki/Jean_Grey_School_for_Higher_Learning "Jean Grey School for
Higher Learning").[41]

As part of the 2012 - 2015 [Marvel NOW!](/wiki/Marvel_NOW! "Marvel NOW!")
relaunch, Wilson rejoins the Avengers after [Iron Man](/wiki/Iron_Man "Iron
Man") and Captain America choose to expand the team's line-up.[42] After
Rogers is aged into an old man, he appoints Wilson as his 'official'
replacement as Captain America.[43] During a confrontation with the Red
Skull's daughter Sin, it is revealed that the "Snap" identity was a fake
memory implanted into Sam by the Red Skull in an attempt to discredit the hero
through racism.[44]

As part of the 2015 [All-New, All-Different Marvel](/wiki/All-New,_All-
Different_Marvel "All-New, All-Different Marvel") initiative, Captain America
investigated the disappearance of Mexican teenager Joaquin Torres after he was
abducted by the [Sons of the Serpent](/wiki/Sons_of_the_Serpent "Sons of the
Serpent").[45] After fighting [Armadillo](/wiki/Armadillo_\(comics\)
"Armadillo \(comics\)") and capturing the leader of the hate group,[46]
Captain America discovered that Joaquin was being used in the experiments of
[Karl Malus](/wiki/Karl_Malus "Karl Malus") who turned Joaquin into a
bird/human hybrid using Captain America's pet bird Redwing. When Karl Malus
was defeated, Captain America took Joaquin in.[47] When it was discovered
Joaquin's bird/human hybrid condition wasn't temporary, Captain America
learned from [Claire Temple](/wiki/Claire_Temple "Claire Temple") that
Joaquin's condition was permanent due to Redwing being vampiric and sporting a
healing factor.[48] When Captain America was captured by the Serpent Society
and thrown out the window by [Viper](/wiki/Viper_\(Marvel_Comics\) "Viper
\(Marvel Comics\)"), he was saved by Joaquin.[49] Using his link with Redwing,
Captain America telepathically sent Joaquin the knowledge on how to fight
where he held his own until [Misty Knight](/wiki/Misty_Knight "Misty Knight")
and [Demolition Man](/wiki/Demolition_Man_\(comics\) "Demolition Man
\(comics\)") showed up. After the Serpent Society was defeated, Captain
America allowed Joaquin to become his sidekick, enabling him to become the new
Falcon.[50]

During the 2016 "[Avengers: Standoff!](/wiki/Avengers:_Standoff! "Avengers:
Standoff!")" storyline, Sam, after defeating the Green Skull, is contacted by
Whisperer (an alias of [Rick Jones](/wiki/Rick_Jones_\(comics\) "Rick Jones
\(comics\)")). After meeting Whisperer, he learns that S.H.I.E.L.D. never
discarded the Kobik project as he thought they did. He meets with Steve
Rogers, where they follow a lead to a town in [Connecticut](/wiki/Connecticut
"Connecticut") and are later picked up by S.H.I.E.L.D. agents.[51] He then
meets the [Winter Soldier](/wiki/Bucky_Barnes "Bucky Barnes") and rescue
S.H.I.E.L.D. agent Avril Kincaid from the [Blood
Brothers](/wiki/Blood_Brothers_\(comics\) "Blood Brothers \(comics\)"), who
informs them of a super-weapon hidden in the town that [Baron
Zemo](/wiki/Baron_Helmut_Zemo "Baron Helmut Zemo") and the other villains are
looking for. They then head to the bowling alley where Kobik uses her powers
to restore Steve Rogers to his prime when he was about to be killed by
[Crossbones](/wiki/Crossbones_\(comics\) "Crossbones \(comics\)"). They begin
looking for Kobik again only to discover that Baron Zemo had
[Fixer](/wiki/Fixer_\(comics\) "Fixer \(comics\)") invent a device that would
help find Kobik as [Kraven the Hunter](/wiki/Kraven_the_Hunter "Kraven the
Hunter") rallies the villains to help with their goals. Upon not being able to
successfully locate Kobik, Steve Rogers decides to rally the heroes so that
they can take the fight to Baron Zemo.[52] In the aftermath of the incident,
Steve and Sam plan to keep what happened at Pleasant Hill under wraps at the
time being.[53]

After the "Standoff!" storyline, Sam begins to face public pressure to return
the shield and mantle of Captain America to Steve, as does Maria Hill for the
consequences of her actions on Pleasant Hill. He and Steve then begin to
secretly plan for a way to get Hill to face her crimes publicly. During a
press conference, Sam encounters the mercenary
[Chance](/wiki/Chance_\(comics\) "Chance \(comics\)") who was about to kill
Steve in the middle of his speech. After defeating him, Sam receives a hero's
welcome when Steve announces him to the public as Captain America. While
getting arrested, Chance tells Sam that he was on Pleasant Hill and that he
didn't agree with the heroes' actions.[54]

During the 2016 "[Civil War II](/wiki/Civil_War_II "Civil War II")" storyline,
Captain America attend [War Machine](/wiki/War_Machine "War Machine")'s
funeral, where he delivers an inspirational speech. Months later, Wilson
watches a TV broadcast about former New Warrior [Rage](/wiki/Rage_\(comics\)
"Rage \(comics\)") engaging in a fight with the [Americops](/wiki/Americop
"Americop"), a private police force funded by Keane Industries, in
[Brooklyn](/wiki/Brooklyn "Brooklyn"). Intending to stop the fight, Wilson,
along with Redwing and Falcon, try to contain the situation. Sam manages to
stop the fight, although not without fighting the Americops, for which he knew
the media would portray him negatively. As he leaves, he is attacked from
behind by [U.S. Agent](/wiki/U.S._Agent_\(comics\) "U.S. Agent \(comics\)").
After a brief argument, Captain America and U.S. Agent begin to fight, with
U.S. Agent gaining the upper hand, until Sam drags him into a tunnel where the
darkness and the great horned owls that reside in it allow him to win the
fight.

After defeating U.S. Agent and receiving an argument from Rage, Wilson returns
to his headquarters where he decides to put a tiny implant in his brain that
will enhance his ability to see what birds see, enabling him to transmit them
into a data storage facility that converts them into images and videos. He
decides to further investigate the Americops to find proof of their violent
activities.[55]

While accompanying Steve Rogers on a mission to stop [Flag-
Smasher](/wiki/Flag-Smasher "Flag-Smasher")'s latest assault, Wilson fails to
save a senator from being shot by the villain, further compromising his
current public image. This is subsequently revealed to have been deliberately
staged by Rogers who has been converted to believe he is a Hydra sleeper agent
since childhood. Using his greater familiarity with the shield, Rogers
deliberately put Wilson in a position where he would be unable to use the
shield to save the senator, with the final goal of demoralizing Sam to the
point where he will return the shield to Rogers of his own free will (not
wanting to kill Wilson and risk creating a martyr).[56]

After discovering that Rage was arrested and accused of robbing a pawn shop
which [Man Mountain Marko](/wiki/Man_Mountain_Marko "Man Mountain Marko") and
[Speed Demon](/wiki/Speed_Demon_\(comics\) "Speed Demon \(comics\)")
committed, Sam offers him professional help from other heroes, but Rage turns
it down, preferring that he should be the one to prove his innocence. After
consulting with his brother and Rogers, Sam posts a video on the internet
showing footage of the Americops beating up Rage, exposing their violent
activities. During Rage's trial, a frustrated Sam leaves the courtroom and
captures Speed Demon, who confesses to his and Man Mountain Marko's
involvement in the pawn shop robbery. Upon returning to the court, Misty tells
Sam that the verdict was already given. While people protest over Rage's
arrest, Sam tries his best to calm them. Sam leaves a letter which explains he
is ending his role as Captain America and returning the shield to Steve
Rogers[57]

During the 2017 "[Secret Empire](/wiki/Secret_Empire_\(comics\) "Secret Empire
\(comics\)")" storyline, Sam has spent time alone in a desert and returns to
the city where he discovers Hydra's takeover and that Steve Rogers is their
leader. Sam rescues a woman and her [Inhuman](/wiki/Inhumans "Inhumans")
daughter from Hydra enforcers, Sam reluctantly helps them to safety. He
reunites with Misty Knight and Demolition Man and helps smuggle other Inhumans
out of the country. He helps [Ant-Man](/wiki/Ant-Man_\(Scott_Lang\) "Ant-Man
\(Scott Lang\)") smuggle his daughter [Cassandra Lang](/wiki/Cassandra_Lang
"Cassandra Lang") then declines their offer to join the underground
resistance.[58] When Hawkeye and the Tony Stark A.I. reveal that Kobik was
responsible for Steve's change, Sam agrees to help smuggle them out of the
country so they can find the Cosmic Cube's fragments.[59] Sam takes the group
through an abandoned subway tunnel where they encounter [Mole
Man](/wiki/Mole_Man "Mole Man"), with whom Sam strikes a deal when they are
attacked by Dreadnoughts sent by Hydra. After crossing the tunnel, the group
departs in a jet plane.[60] They arrive in a mansion where
[Ultron](/wiki/Ultron "Ultron") resides, since he is in possession of the
shard. They encounter Steve Rogers and his Avengers until Ultron captures
them. After a brief battle, Ultron allows them to leave and gives the shard to
Tony's team. Steve muses that he is unconcerned about who will acquire the
fragments as he has an inside man in the Tony Stark A.I.'s team.[61]

After a series of dead ends, the team returns to the hideout, where Sam
reunites with Misty, until Hydra forces arrive and begin their assault on the
base. During the battle, Sam helps the other heroes in protecting the refugees
and battling Hydra's Avengers and a revived Bruce Banner as the Hulk until the
base explodes.[62] In the aftermath of the attack, Sam appears standing on top
of the rubble as Captain America to inspire the resistance to not
surrender.[63] It is later revealed that Sam had a conversation with Misty
Knight and Rayshaun Lucas, the new [Patriot](/wiki/Patriot_\(comics\) "Patriot
\(comics\)"), which has persuaded him to reassume the role of Captain America,
leading the resistance and wielding Rogers' original round shield as a symbol
of hope.[64] Sam uses the Cosmic Cube fragment acquired by the resistance to
help destroy the Darforce dome surrounding Manhattan and the planetary defense
shield, releasing all the trapped heroes. Liberating all the imprisoned
Inhumans, the Underground attacks the Capitol which attracts the attention of
Steve Rogers, who arrives wearing Cosmic Cube-powered armor. During the final
battle, Sam fakes surrender and gives the fragment to Steve, only for Winter
Soldier to intervene and bring Kobik and the real Steve Rogers back. The
restored Steve Rogers manages to defeat the Hydra Steve Rogers with Thor's
hammer and Kobik restores reality back to normal.[65]

### Return as
Falcon[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Falcon_\(comics\)&action=edit&section=7 "Edit
section: Return as Falcon")]

Upon taking the second [Patriot](/wiki/Patriot_\(comics\) "Patriot
\(comics\)") on as his sidekick, they travel to [Chicago](/wiki/Chicago
"Chicago") to deal with an outbreak of gang violence, unaware that
[Blackheart](/wiki/Blackheart "Blackheart") is posing as the city's Mayor.[66]

## Powers, abilities, and
equipment[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Falcon_\(comics\)&action=edit&section=8
"Edit section: Powers, abilities, and equipment")]

### Powers[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Falcon_\(comics\)&action=edit&section=9
"Edit section: Powers")]

In his earliest appearances, Wilson exhibits a close bond with his bird
Redwing, which is confirmed as being a telepathic link by [Professor
X](/wiki/Professor_X "Professor X") in _Captain America_ #174. The [Red
Skull](/wiki/Red_Skull "Red Skull") later reveals that he had used the [Cosmic
Cube](/wiki/Cosmic_Cube "Cosmic Cube") to create a "super-normal mental link"
between Sam Wilson and Redwing.[67] Falcon later recalled the experience,
stating "Hurt like _hell_. Being mentally _fused_ with that falcon. Able to
_see_ through _his_ eyes."[68]

Wilson eventually revealed that he has been able to extend this empathic link.
"I'm always psychically connected with Redwing, but through concentration,
I've recently tapped into another ability – I'm able to link-up with other
birds. ... I have over six _billion_ pairs of eyes in the United States
alone." He used this ability to quickly search New York City when the criminal
[Scarecrow](/wiki/Scarecrow_\(Marvel_Comics\) "Scarecrow \(Marvel Comics\)")
kidnapped two children,[69] as well as to spy on Senator Dell Rusk (actually
the Red Skull in disguise) and Henry Peter Gyrich.[70] He is also apparently
able to access the memories of birds, and see things they had witnessed in the
past (although birds have a different concept of the passage of time, which
makes it difficult for him to know when any events they witnessed
occurred).[71]

###
Abilities[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Falcon_\(comics\)&action=edit&section=10
"Edit section: Abilities")]

Wilson is a skilled hand-to-hand combatant, having been trained in
[Judo](/wiki/Judo "Judo")[72] and [Karate](/wiki/Karate "Karate")[73] by Steve
Rogers. Wilson is also highly-skilled in the use of Captain America's
[shield](/wiki/Captain_America%27s_shield "Captain America's
shield").[_[volume & issue needed](/wiki/Wikipedia:Citing_sources
"Wikipedia:Citing sources")_]

### Uniform and flight
harness[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Falcon_\(comics\)&action=edit&section=11
"Edit section: Uniform and flight harness")]

Wilson's original Falcon wing harness featured detachable jet-powered glider
wings made of lightweight titanium ribbing and Mylar. The wings were covered
with wafer-thin solar power receptors that convert sunlight into electricity
to power miniature high-speed electric turbine fans in his uniform and boots.
The wings detached and reattached to his uniform cybernetically. The harness
was destroyed in _[Captain America and the
Falcon](/wiki/Captain_America_and_the_Falcon "Captain America and the
Falcon")_ #2 (2004). The uniform was made of synthetic stretch fabric lined
with a steel-alloy mesh.[_[volume & issue
needed](/wiki/Wikipedia:Citing_sources "Wikipedia:Citing sources")_]

After the original flying harness's destruction in a 2004 storyline,[74] the
[Black Panther](/wiki/Black_Panther_\(comics\) "Black Panther \(comics\)")
supplied Falcon with a new costume and wings. An emitter array on Falcon's
back creates holographic "hard light" wings with a maximum wingspan of up to
50 feet (15 m). Controlled by a cybernetic link, the wings can be instantly
reconfigured into "dozens of different cruise configurations". A "magnetic
drive", in turn, provides the thrust needed to get Falcon airborne. The
emitter also possesses GPS jamming devices that prevent
[satellite](/wiki/Satellite "Satellite") tracking, while the hard-light wings
interfere with infra-red tracking. A [vibranium](/wiki/Vibranium "Vibranium")
microweave was added to the costume itself, making Falcon resistant to small
arms fire.[75] The entire system is controlled mentally through cybernetic
circuitry in the Falcon's mask. The costume has in the past featured a hidden
"talon," a cybernetically controlled grappling line built into the gauntlets
of his costume which he uses to entangle opponents, hook objects, or for
swinging and climbing when his wings are detached. The costume's visors come
equipped with various capabilities, including infrared lenses, giving him the
ability to see objects by their infrared signature at night, magnification
capabilities, and remote imaging sensors that allow a full 360 degree of
vision when activated. The cowl also has a wide band receiver and transmitter
with an unspecified range. The suit was originally built by the Black
Panther,[76] with costume modifications by Desmond Burrell.[_[volume & issue
needed](/wiki/Wikipedia:Citing_sources "Wikipedia:Citing sources")_]

## Other characters named
Falcon[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Falcon_\(comics\)&action=edit&section=12
"Edit section: Other characters named Falcon")]

### Joaquin
Torres[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Falcon_\(comics\)&action=edit&section=13
"Edit section: Joaquin Torres")]

As part of the 2015 [All-New, All-Different Marvel](/wiki/All-New,_All-
Different_Marvel "All-New, All-Different Marvel") branding, Captain America
(Sam Wilson) investigated the disappearance of Mexican teenager Joaquin Torres
after he was abducted by the [Sons of the Serpent](/wiki/Sons_of_the_Serpent
"Sons of the Serpent").[45] Captain America discovered that Joaquin was being
used in the experiments of [Karl Malus](/wiki/Karl_Malus "Karl Malus") who
turned Joaquin into a bird/human hybrid using Captain America's pet bird
Redwing. When Karl Malus was defeated, Captain America took Joaquin in.[47]
When it was discovered Joaquin's bird/human hybrid condition wasn't temporary,
Captain America learned from [Claire Temple](/wiki/Claire_Temple "Claire
Temple") that Joaquin's condition was permanent due to Redwing being vampiric
and sporting a healing factor.[48] When Captain America was captured by the
Serpent Society and thrown out the window by
[Viper](/wiki/Viper_\(Marvel_Comics\) "Viper \(Marvel Comics\)"), he was saved
by Joaquin.[49] Using his link with Redwing, Captain America telepathically
sent Joaquin the knowledge on how to fight where he held his own until [Misty
Knight](/wiki/Misty_Knight "Misty Knight") and [Demolition
Man](/wiki/Demolition_Man_\(comics\) "Demolition Man \(comics\)") showed up.
After the Serpent Society was defeated, Captain America allowed Joaquin to
become his sidekick, enabling him to become the new Falcon.[50]

During the "[Secret Empire](/wiki/Secret_Empire_\(comic_book\) "Secret Empire
\(comic book\)")" storyline, Falcon II and [Ironheart](/wiki/Riri_Williams
"Riri Williams") join the [Champions](/wiki/Champions_\(2016_team\) "Champions
\(2016 team\)") when they join up with the Underground.[77]>

### Adrian
Toomes[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Falcon_\(comics\)&action=edit&section=14
"Edit section: Adrian Toomes")]

Main article: [Vulture (Marvel Comics)](/wiki/Vulture_\(Marvel_Comics\)
"Vulture \(Marvel Comics\)")

In a 2017 storyline, Adrian Toomes developed a modified version of his
Electromagnetic Wing Harness that has a reinforced helmet and lightweight,
razor-sharp, nano-woven wings which responded to his mental commands where he
took on the name Falcon where he believed the name to be vacant at the time.
He robbed a location in East Village where he fought Spider-Man until they
were immobilized by a new [Trapster](/wiki/Trapster "Trapster") who made off
with Falcon's loot.[78]

## Other
versions[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Falcon_\(comics\)&action=edit&section=16
"Edit section: Other versions")]

  * In the alternate reality of a 1983 _[What If?](/wiki/What_If_\(comics\) "What If \(comics\)") story, Sam - under his gang name "Snap" \- is a member of a secret rebellion force in a United States turned fascist who aids Captain America in beating [an impostor](/wiki/Captain_America_\(William_Burnside\) "Captain America \(William Burnside\)") and leading the chastised nation back to its democratic roots.[79]_
  * Sam Wilson / Falcon appears as one of the zombified heroes in the _[Marvel Zombies](/wiki/Marvel_Zombies "Marvel Zombies")_ universe. Initially, he is among the many heroes summoned by Nick Fury to fight off the infection, but he winds up being infected.[_[volume & issue needed](/wiki/Wikipedia:Citing_sources "Wikipedia:Citing sources")_] Afterwards, in _[Marvel Zombies 3](/wiki/Marvel_Zombies_3 "Marvel Zombies 3")_ , he, along with other wing-laden characters ([Angel](/wiki/Warren_Worthington_III "Warren Worthington III"), [Beak](/wiki/Barnell_Bohusk "Barnell Bohusk") and [Vulture](/wiki/Vulture_\(Marvel_Comics\) "Vulture \(Marvel Comics\)")), attack [Machine Man](/wiki/Machine_Man "Machine Man"), Ultron and [Jocasta](/wiki/Jocasta_\(comics\) "Jocasta \(comics\)") as soon as they arrive in this ravaged universe, but he and the others are quickly killed by Machine Man.[80]
  * In _Amazing[Spider-Girl](/wiki/Spider-Girl "Spider-Girl")_ #7, which is part of the [MC2](/wiki/Marvel_Comics_2 "Marvel Comics 2") universe, Wilson was revealed to be dead. However, the [Ladyhawk](/wiki/Ladyhawk_\(comics\) "Ladyhawk \(comics\)") twins wear attire similar to his first costume, from before he had the mantle of either Falcon or Captain America.
  * In the "Once and Future King" story arc from _Black Panther_ , a retired Sam Wilson is shown as the mayor of New York City 25 years into the future. He comes out of retirement for one final mission to help Black Panther defeat T'charra, T'Chaka's treasonous son.[81]

[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/en/thumb/b/bb/Ultimate_Falcon.jpg/170px-
Ultimate_Falcon.jpg)](/wiki/File:Ultimate_Falcon.jpg)

[](/wiki/File:Ultimate_Falcon.jpg "Enlarge")

The [Ultimate Marvel](/wiki/Ultimate_Marvel "Ultimate Marvel") version of
Falcon on the cover of _[Ultimate Comics: The
Ultimates](/wiki/Ultimate_Comics:_The_Ultimates "Ultimate Comics: The
Ultimates")_ #7 (April 2012). Art by [Kaare Andrews](/wiki/Kaare_Andrews
"Kaare Andrews").

  * In the [Ultimate Marvel](/wiki/Ultimate_Marvel "Ultimate Marvel") universe, Samuel Wilson is an explorer, adventurer, and scientist who uses a backpack with high-tech folding wings to fly as the **Eagle**. Wilson first appeared in _[Ultimate Nightmare](/wiki/Ultimate_Galactus_trilogy#Ultimate_Nightmare "Ultimate Galactus trilogy")_ and then worked on the [Vision](/wiki/Vision_\(Marvel_Comics\) "Vision \(Marvel Comics\)"), demonstrating a high level of technological understanding and confronted [George Tarleton](/wiki/M.O.D.O.K. "M.O.D.O.K.") of [A.I.M.](/wiki/Advanced_Idea_Mechanics "Advanced Idea Mechanics") aboard a space station studying a [Gah Lak Tus](/wiki/Gah_Lak_Tus "Gah Lak Tus") module.[82] He is an agent of S.H.I.E.L.D. rather than an official member of [the Ultimates](/wiki/The_Ultimates "The Ultimates") or Reserves. He has served with or under General [Nick Fury](/wiki/Ultimate_Nick_Fury "Ultimate Nick Fury"), and was a member of the armed forces but retired to pursue scientific interests. This version appears to be an accomplished combatant, especially when using the sharp edge of the metal wings he wears as a weapon, which are controlled through the help of [nanotechnology](/wiki/Nanotechnology "Nanotechnology"), with which he can communicate and retrieve computer information. The wings are partially self-repairing, as referenced in _[Ultimate Extinction](/wiki/Ultimate_Extinction "Ultimate Extinction")_.[83]
  * In Marvel's [MAX](/wiki/MAX_\(comics\) "MAX \(comics\)") [imprint](/wiki/Imprint_\(trade_name\) "Imprint \(trade name\)") series _[U.S. War Machine](/wiki/War_Machine "War Machine")_ , Wilson appeared alongside [Captain America](/wiki/Captain_America "Captain America") and [Hawkeye](/wiki/Hawkeye_\(comics\) "Hawkeye \(comics\)"); he and [Hawkeye](/wiki/Hawkeye_\(comics\) "Hawkeye \(comics\)") served as [Captain America](/wiki/Captain_America "Captain America")'s backup and wore no costumes, only being addressed by their real names. In this reality, [Captain America](/wiki/Captain_America "Captain America") was actually [Bucky](/wiki/Bucky_Barnes "Bucky Barnes") wearing the Captain's uniform as here the Captain had died in [World War II](/wiki/World_War_II "World War II") in his stead.
  * In the 2006 comic _[What If Captain America had fought in the Civil War?](/wiki/What_If_\(comics\) "What If \(comics\)")_ , the [Earth-717](/wiki/Earth-717 "Earth-717") version of Wilson was an orphan raised by a [Shawnee](/wiki/Shawnee "Shawnee") [medicine man](/wiki/Medicine_man "Medicine man"), and grew up to fight in the [American Civil War](/wiki/American_Civil_War "American Civil War") as part of an Indian volunteer regiment. He performs a ritual to give Steven Rogers the power of We-Pi-Ahk, the Eagle Spirit, and has a red eagle painted on his chest for this ceremony. He is killed by [Colonel Barnes](/wiki/Bucky_Barnes "Bucky Barnes") (who in this reality is the White Skull).
  * In the "[Heroes Reborn](/wiki/Heroes_Reborn_\(comics\) "Heroes Reborn \(comics\)")" universe, created by [Franklin Richards](/wiki/Franklin_Richards_\(Fantastic_Four\) "Franklin Richards \(Fantastic Four\)"), a version of Samuel Wilson appears. His father, Abraham "Abe" Wilson fought alongside Captain America during [World War II](/wiki/World_War_II "World War II"), but is later killed by [Master Man](/wiki/Master_Man_\(Marvel_Comics\) "Master Man \(Marvel Comics\)")'s army.[84] During the fight, Abe's son Sam Wilson is shot in a fight and gravely wounded, but Captain America saves his life by giving him a transfusion of the Super-Soldier's own blood. Consequently, Wilson gains superhuman abilities comparable to those of Captain America. His military nickname, "The Falcon", becomes his superhero code name, avenges his father by beating Master Man, and along with Captain America, and [Nick Fury](/wiki/Nick_Fury "Nick Fury") defeat the [Red Skull](/wiki/Red_Skull "Red Skull")'s plans for world domination.[85]
  * In an alternate timeline seen in _[Avengers: The Children's Crusade](/wiki/Avengers:_The_Children%27s_Crusade "Avengers: The Children's Crusade")_, Sam was succeeded as the Falcon by his daughter Samantha. Samantha is shown as a member of the Avengers alongside her husband [Eli](/wiki/Elijah_Bradley "Elijah Bradley") (the new Captain America), and their son Steve (the new [Bucky](/wiki/Bucky_Barnes "Bucky Barnes")).[86]
  * In _[Daredevil: End of Days](/wiki/Daredevil:_End_of_Days "Daredevil: End of Days")_ , Wilson is briefly shown as the future president of the United States of America.[87]
  * During the _[Secret Wars](/wiki/Secret_Wars_\(2015\) "Secret Wars \(2015\)")_ storyline, an alternate, naturally-winged version of Sam Wilson is a member of the Thor Corps (which are the police force of [Battleworld](/wiki/Battleworld "Battleworld")). He and the Thor Corps members arrest [Miss America](/wiki/Miss_America_\(America_Chavez\) "Miss America \(America Chavez\)") after she violates [Doom](/wiki/Doctor_Doom "Doctor Doom")'s laws by throwing a [Megalodon](/wiki/Megalodon "Megalodon") that attacked Arcadia far enough to go over the Shield and end up in the Deadlands.[88]
  * A female version of Sam Wilson (Samantha T. Wilson) serves as the original Captain America of the _[Spider-Gwen](/wiki/Spider-Gwen "Spider-Gwen")_ universe of Earth-65. When World War II struck, she became one of the first black female pilots in the U.S. military. Eventually, she was recruited into Project Rebirth, and was chosen to undergo the procedure when the other candidates [Bucky](/wiki/Bucky_Barnes "Bucky Barnes"), [Steve Rogers](/wiki/Captain_America "Captain America"), and [Isaiah Bradley](/wiki/Isaiah_Bradley "Isaiah Bradley") were badly injured by Nazi agents. After this, she became Captain America, and fought the Nazis. When the Nazis attempted to summon creatures from another dimension, she entered said dimension to hold off the invading forces, un-aging in this reality for nearly 75 years. When she finally defeated them and returned to her home dimension of Earth-65, she was recruited by S.H.I.E.L.D. director Peggy Carter to continue her service as Captain America as one of her agents.[89]
  * Another version of Sam Wilson appears in the _[Spider-Gwen](/wiki/Spider-Gwen "Spider-Gwen")_ universe of Earth-65. He is the male clone of Samantha Wilson and is also this universe's Falcon where he works as Captain America's sidekick. Falcon is known as Sam 13 and is an expert sniper-assassin. He is aided by Redwing (who in this reality is a robotic falcon) where Sam 13 used him for assault and reconnaissance. Falcon and Redwing first come into contact with Spider-Woman while she was fighting Lizard.[89]

## In other
media[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Falcon_\(comics\)&action=edit&section=17 "Edit
section: In other media")]

###
Television[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Falcon_\(comics\)&action=edit&section=18
"Edit section: Television")]

  * Falcon (along with his bird Redwing) appeared as a member of the Avengers in the television series _[The Avengers: United They Stand](/wiki/The_Avengers:_United_They_Stand "The Avengers: United They Stand")_ , voiced by Martin Roach.[_[citation needed](/wiki/Wikipedia:Citation_needed "Wikipedia:Citation needed")_]
  * Falcon along with his bird Redwing appears in _[The Super Hero Squad Show](/wiki/The_Super_Hero_Squad_Show "The Super Hero Squad Show")_ , with Falcon voiced by [Alimi Ballard](/wiki/Alimi_Ballard "Alimi Ballard") and Redwing's vocal effects provided by [Steven Blum](/wiki/Steven_Blum "Steven Blum").[90] In this version, he is capable of launching his "feathers" at his enemies.
  * Sam Wilson / Falcon appears in _[The Avengers: Earth's Mightiest Heroes](/wiki/The_Avengers:_Earth%27s_Mightiest_Heroes "The Avengers: Earth's Mightiest Heroes")_, voiced by [Lance Reddick](/wiki/Lance_Reddick "Lance Reddick").[91] Alongside Doc Samson, Falcon is a mind-controlled servant of [Dell Rusk](/wiki/Red_Skull "Red Skull"). He appears in the episodes "Nightmare in Red", "Code Red", and "Avengers Assemble!".
  * Sam Wilson / Falcon appears as one of the main characters in the _[Avengers Assemble](/wiki/Avengers_Assemble_\(TV_series\) "Avengers Assemble \(TV series\)")_ animated series, voiced by [Bumper Robinson](/wiki/Bumper_Robinson "Bumper Robinson").[92][93] This iteration of Sam Wilson is depicted as a 17-year-old S.H.I.E.L.D. operative that [Iron Man](/wiki/Iron_Man "Iron Man") had an eye on. When the Avengers brought together to save [Captain America](/wiki/Captain_America "Captain America") from the Red Skull, Sam was originally offered the [War Machine](/wiki/War_Machine "War Machine") armor, but turned it down in favor of the Falcon armor. Wilson later dons a new version of his Falcon armor where there is a beak-shaped visor over his eyes. The wing pack is capable of detaching itself from the rest of the armor to become "Redwing Mode" and fly by itself to the point where it can whip up tornadoes. In the fourth season, Falcon is kidnapped by [Kang the Conqueror](/wiki/Kang_the_Conqueror "Kang the Conqueror") and spends years in the future working with him to stop a black hole from destroying the Earth. When he returns to the present, he is significantly older and has a new outfit that greatly resembles his outfit in the MCU.
  * Sam Wilson appears in _[Ultimate Spider-Man: Web Warriors](/wiki/Ultimate_Spider-Man_\(TV_series\) "Ultimate Spider-Man \(TV series\)")_ , voiced again by Bumper Robinson.[94] He appears in the episodes "Avenging Spider-Man" [Parts 1 and 2] and "Contest of Champions" [Part 4].
  * Sam Wilson appears in the _[Lego Marvel Super Heroes: Maximum Overload](/wiki/Lego_Marvel_Super_Heroes:_Maximum_Overload "Lego Marvel Super Heroes: Maximum Overload")_ mini-series, voiced again by Bumper Robinson.[_[citation needed](/wiki/Wikipedia:Citation_needed "Wikipedia:Citation needed")_]
  * Falcon appears in the Japanese [anime](/wiki/Anime "Anime") series _[Marvel Disk Wars: The Avengers](/wiki/Marvel_Disk_Wars:_The_Avengers "Marvel Disk Wars: The Avengers")_ , voiced by [Kaito Ishikawa](/wiki/Kaito_Ishikawa "Kaito Ishikawa") in the Japanese version.[_[citation needed](/wiki/Wikipedia:Citation_needed "Wikipedia:Citation needed")_]

Soldier](/wiki/Captain_America:_The_Winter_Soldier "Captain America: The
Winter Soldier")_

  * [Anthony Mackie](/wiki/Anthony_Mackie "Anthony Mackie") portrays Sam Wilson in the [Marvel Cinematic Universe](/wiki/Marvel_Cinematic_Universe "Marvel Cinematic Universe"), with the character's first appearance being in the 2014 film _[Captain America: The Winter Soldier](/wiki/Captain_America:_The_Winter_Soldier "Captain America: The Winter Soldier")_.[95][96] In the film, Wilson uses a pair of [submachine guns](/wiki/Submachine_gun "Submachine gun") as his main weapons and flies using a [jet pack](/wiki/Jet_pack "Jet pack") with articulated wings.[97] Mackie reprises the role in the 2015 films _[Avengers: Age of Ultron](/wiki/Avengers:_Age_of_Ultron "Avengers: Age of Ultron")_ ,[98] _[Ant-Man](/wiki/Ant-Man_\(film\) "Ant-Man \(film\)")_ ,[99] the 2016 film _[Captain America: Civil War](/wiki/Captain_America:_Civil_War "Captain America: Civil War")_ , [100][101] and _[Avengers: Infinity War](/wiki/Avengers:_Infinity_War "Avengers: Infinity War")_.[102] Redwing makes a first appearance in _Civil War_ as Falcon's bird-shaped robotic drone.[103]

### Theatre[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Falcon_\(comics\)&action=edit&section=20
"Edit section: Theatre")]

  * Sam Wilson appears in the _[Marvel Universe: LIVE!](/wiki/Marvel_Universe:_LIVE! "Marvel Universe: LIVE!")_ arena [stage show](/wiki/Stage_show "Stage show").[104]

### Video
games[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Falcon_\(comics\)&action=edit&section=21 "Edit
section: Video games")]

  * Falcon appears as a playable character in the _[Marvel Super Hero Squad](/wiki/Marvel_Super_Hero_Squad_\(video_game\) "Marvel Super Hero Squad \(video game\)")_ video game and its sequel _[Marvel Super Hero Squad: The Infinity Gauntlet](/wiki/Marvel_Super_Hero_Squad:_The_Infinity_Gauntlet "Marvel Super Hero Squad: The Infinity Gauntlet")_ , with Alimi Ballard reprising the role.
  * Falcon is once again a playable character in the game _[Marvel Super Hero Squad: Comic Combat](/wiki/Marvel_Super_Hero_Squad:_Comic_Combat "Marvel Super Hero Squad: Comic Combat")_ , with Alimi Ballard voicing the role.
  * Falcon is a playable character in _[Marvel Super Hero Squad Online](/wiki/Marvel_Super_Hero_Squad_Online "Marvel Super Hero Squad Online")_.
  * Falcon appears as [DLC](/wiki/Downloadable_content "Downloadable content") in _[Lego Marvel Super Heroes](/wiki/Lego_Marvel_Super_Heroes "Lego Marvel Super Heroes")_ ,[105] voiced by [Andrew Kishino](/wiki/Andrew_Kishino "Andrew Kishino").
  * Falcon appears in the [Facebook](/wiki/Facebook "Facebook") game _[Marvel: Avengers Alliance](/wiki/Marvel:_Avengers_Alliance "Marvel: Avengers Alliance")_.[106] He appears in the 17th Spec Ops game loosely based upon the events of _Captain America: The Winter Soldier_.
  * The MCU version of Falcon appears as a Team-Up character in _[Marvel Heroes](/wiki/Marvel_Heroes_\(video_game\) "Marvel Heroes \(video game\)")_ ,[107] voiced by [Bumper Robinson](/wiki/Bumper_Robinson "Bumper Robinson").[_[citation needed](/wiki/Wikipedia:Citation_needed "Wikipedia:Citation needed")_] An alternate version of Captain America is later added to the game.[108]
  * Falcon appears as a playable character in _[Disney Infinity: Marvel Super Heroes](/wiki/Disney_Infinity:_Marvel_Super_Heroes "Disney Infinity: Marvel Super Heroes")_ ,[109] with Bumper Robinson reprising the role.[_[citation needed](/wiki/Wikipedia:Citation_needed "Wikipedia:Citation needed")_] Falcon's wings are also available as a usable vehicle for other heroes.[110] Falcon also appears in _[Disney Infinity 3.0](/wiki/Disney_Infinity_3.0 "Disney Infinity 3.0")_.[_[citation needed](/wiki/Wikipedia:Citation_needed "Wikipedia:Citation needed")_]
  * The MCU version of Falcon appears as a playable character in _[Marvel: Future Fight](/wiki/Marvel:_Future_Fight "Marvel: Future Fight")_.[111] An alternate version of Captain America is later added to celebrate the 4th of July.[_[citation needed](/wiki/Wikipedia:Citation_needed "Wikipedia:Citation needed")_]
  * Falcon is a playable character in _[Lego Marvel's Avengers](/wiki/Lego_Marvel%27s_Avengers "Lego Marvel's Avengers")_,[112] voiced by [Anthony Mackie](/wiki/Anthony_Mackie "Anthony Mackie").[_[citation needed](/wiki/Wikipedia:Citation_needed "Wikipedia:Citation needed")_] He is initially available in his Classic and _Captain America: The Winter Soldier_ designs along with his Captain America appearance. Falcon's _Captain America: Civil War_ appearance is available through DLC.
  * Falcon appears as a playable character in _Playmation: Avengers_.[113]
  * A teenage version of Falcon appears as a playable character in _[Marvel Avengers Academy](/wiki/Marvel_Avengers_Academy "Marvel Avengers Academy")_ , voiced by [A$AP Rocky](/wiki/A$AP_Rocky "A$AP Rocky").[114]
  * Falcon is a playable character in the match-three mobile game _[Marvel Puzzle Quest](/wiki/Marvel_Puzzle_Quest "Marvel Puzzle Quest")_. Captain America is added to the game in August 2015.[115]

##
Reception[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Falcon_\(comics\)&action=edit&section=22
"Edit section: Reception")]

Wilson was placed as the 96th greatest comic book hero by [IGN](/wiki/IGN
"IGN"), which opined that the partnership between him and Steve Rogers forms
one of the greatest crime fighting duos in comics,[116] and as #45 on their
list of the "Top 50 Avengers".[117]
